title: How do i protect my credit if my husband stops paying on his credit cards that are in his name only ?
question: me and my husband are split up but not divorced. he is going to stop paying his credit cards and im just wondering what will happen to my credit, we have no joint debt except the house which he will keep paying on, but can they garnish my wages even though i am not on the credit cards? i have good credit that i dont want tarnished. how do i protect myself? legal seperation? we are trying to avoid divorce since we live in california.
answers: Your credit will not be affected by your husband's decision not to pay his credit cards. Although you may technically be liable for the debts since they are community debts, it is extremely unlikely that the creditors will sue you for your husband's debts while you were living together on the basis that you might be liable because of community property laws. A creditor can only garnish wages when it has a judgment. A judgment requires that you be served with court papers and given an opportunity to have a trial. If you are sued you must seek legal representation to protect yourself from having a judgment entered against you. I seriously doubt that you will be sued for your husband's credit card debt. There is nothing you need to do to protect yourself except not ignoring any lawsuits against you even if the lawsuit has no legal merit.

I would suggest that you monitor your credit carefully while your husband is chosing to play this game. In some instances, community property laws could result in you being legally responsible for paying your husband's credit card debts, but it is extremely unlikely.

If your husband's debts show up on your credit report, you will want to contact the credit bureaus to dispute that you owe these debts and follow up.

Hope this perspective helps & good luck!

Divorce, separation and other legal measures will not act to protect or harm your credit rating. If you did not use, gaurantee or use your income to as support to sign up for the cards, and you have no liability for the debt, your credit score should not be affected. Does a spouses bad credit information end up on the other spouses credit report? yes. But it should not. Joint debt will affect your credit score.

The divorce agreement, decree or judgment supposedly settled the rights and obligations between you and the former spouse. However, it does not change the obligations each of you had with third parties who were not in Court when you got the divorce.

The ex-spouse may refuse to make payments to credit card companies, car financing companies, mortgage companies, etc. Your ex may even file for Bankruptcy.

Depending on the law in your State you may have an action against the ex-spouse, and you may even be able to sue the ex-spouse if they file for Bankruptcy and have their obligation to you declared “non-dischargeable”.

Unfortunately the divorce or the ex’s Bankruptcy does not relieve you of any obligations you had to these third parties.
